column4: More policing and more jails have already proven to be ineffective solutions to decreasing crime and making our communities safe. It’s time for new solutions, like funding community programs, addressing root causes of crime, and enacting real anti-poverty policy in the city. /7

It’s also time to elect authentically progressive candidates into local office who will bring new solutions to the table, not accept toxic $ from police unions, & not cave in the face of law and order/tough on crime stances which are sure to run rampant this election season. /8

The police killings of Oscar Cain & Jimmy Atchison (both in 2019) are among the cases in the exhaustive backlog Willis decries & insists more policing will help solve. She’s also continued to try to recuse herself from difficult cases involving police brutality & shootings. /6

While Willis decries the criminal justice system’s issue of perpetual backlog, she fails to recognize that the APD are regular contributors to this backlog through their own acts of state sanctioned gun violence and other forms of misconduct. /5

Yesterday's report from @ajc didn't do much except to echo a recent Facebook post by Willis that displayed incendiary calls to embolden a police system that is already set to receive 10% increase in the city budget, more officers, & more surveillance. /4\n\nhttps://t.co/OlTjnmHJdG

We fact-checked Willis’ campaign finance reports & cross-referenced w/ an account provided by former progressive FCDA candidate Christian Wise Smith. Hear about his meeting w/ Willis & T.I. following last year’s primary in an interview here. (26:52) /3\n\nhttps://t.co/KWaitrn0m7

This important detail is a fact that the @ajc continues to ignore or omit from their reports on the new DA. We’ve reported on this numerous times, as in the most recent available updates regarding the Brooks, Pilgrim, & Young police brutality cases. /2\n\nhttps://t.co/l0gjPStL1d

Friendly reminder that Fulton County DA Fani Willis was endorsed & funded by the International Brotherhood of Police & Mary Norwood, so she probably doesn’t have the most reliable outlook on how we should address crime in our city. @ajc /1\n\nhttps://t.co/mHfYmxl7TS
